p: The interactions between air quality and health are direct and indirect (Fig. 1). First, particles, especially from combustion, can affect cardiopulmonary mortality, hospitalization and respiratory disease (e.g. asthma, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis) [ 3]. Recent evidence supports associations with diabetes [ 21], rheumatic diseases [ 22], cognitive functioning [ 23] and neurodegenerative diseases [ 24]. Furthermore, gases such as the secondary pollutant ozone are related to all-cause, circulatory and respiratory mortalities [ 3, 25] as well as chronic respiratory diseases such as asthma [ 3]. Studies have connected higher ozone concentrations with preterm birth [ 26], reproductive health [ 27] and cognitive decline [ 24].
